segment.source: Monitor app usage with AppLocker (Windows 10)
segment.target: Monitor app usage with AppLocker (Windows 10)

segment.source: This topic for IT professionals describes how to monitor app usage when AppLocker policies are applied.
segment.target: This topic for IT professionals describes how to monitor app usage when AppLocker policies are applied.

segment.source: Monitor app usage with AppLocker
segment.target: Monitor app usage with AppLocker

segment.source: Applies to
segment.target: Applies to

segment.source: Windows 10
segment.target: Windows 10

segment.source: This topic for IT professionals describes how to monitor app usage when AppLocker policies are applied.
segment.target: This topic for IT professionals describes how to monitor app usage when AppLocker policies are applied.

segment.source: Once you set rules and deploy the AppLocker policies, it is good practice to determine if the policy implementation is what you expected.
segment.target: Once you set rules and deploy the AppLocker policies, it is good practice to determine if the policy implementation is what you expected.

segment.source: Discover the effect of an AppLocker policy
segment.target: Discover the effect of an AppLocker policy

segment.source: You can evaluate how the AppLocker policy is currently implemented for documentation or audit purposes, or before you modify the policy.
segment.target: You can evaluate how the AppLocker policy is currently implemented for documentation or audit purposes, or before you modify the policy.

segment.source: Updating your AppLocker Policy Deployment Planning document will help you track your findings.
segment.target: Updating your AppLocker Policy Deployment Planning document will help you track your findings.

segment.source: For information about creating this document, see Create your AppLocker planning document.
segment.target: For information about creating this document, see Create your AppLocker planning document.

segment.source: You can perform one or more of the following steps to understand what application controls are currently enforced through AppLocker rules.
segment.target: You can perform one or more of the following steps to understand what application controls are currently enforced through AppLocker rules.

segment.source: Analyze the AppLocker logs in Event Viewer
segment.target: Analyze the AppLocker logs in Event Viewer

segment.source: When AppLocker policy enforcement is set to Enforce rules, rules are enforced for the rule collection and all events are audited.
segment.target: When AppLocker policy enforcement is set to Enforce rules, rules are enforced for the rule collection and all events are audited.

segment.source: When AppLocker policy enforcement is set to Audit only, rules are not enforced but are still evaluated to generate audit event data that is written to the AppLocker logs.
segment.target: When AppLocker policy enforcement is set to Audit only, rules are not enforced but are still evaluated to generate audit event data that is written to the AppLocker logs.

segment.source: For the procedure to access the log, see View the AppLocker Log in Event Viewer.
segment.target: For the procedure to access the log, see View the AppLocker Log in Event Viewer.

segment.source: Enable the Audit only AppLocker enforcement setting
segment.target: Enable the Audit only AppLocker enforcement setting

segment.source: By using the Audit only enforcement setting, you can ensure that the AppLocker rules are properly configured for your organization.
segment.target: By using the Audit only enforcement setting, you can ensure that the AppLocker rules are properly configured for your organization.

segment.source: When AppLocker policy enforcement is set to Audit only, rules are only evaluated but all events generated from that evaluation are written to the AppLocker log.
segment.target: When AppLocker policy enforcement is set to Audit only, rules are only evaluated but all events generated from that evaluation are written to the AppLocker log.

segment.source: For the procedure to do this, see Configure an AppLocker policy for audit only.
segment.target: For the procedure to do this, see Configure an AppLocker policy for audit only.

segment.source: Review AppLocker events with Get-AppLockerFileInformation
segment.target: Review AppLocker events with Get-AppLockerFileInformation

segment.source: For both event subscriptions and local events, you can use the Get-AppLockerFileInformation Windows PowerShell cmdlet to determine which files have been blocked or would have been blocked (if you are using the audit-only enforcement mode) and how many times the event has occurred for each file.
segment.target: For both event subscriptions and local events, you can use the Get-AppLockerFileInformation Windows PowerShell cmdlet to determine which files have been blocked or would have been blocked (if you are using the audit-only enforcement mode) and how many times the event has occurred for each file.

segment.source: For the procedure to do this, see Review AppLocker Events with Get-AppLockerFileInformation.
segment.target: For the procedure to do this, see Review AppLocker Events with Get-AppLockerFileInformation.

segment.source: Review AppLocker events with Test-AppLockerPolicy
segment.target: Review AppLocker events with Test-AppLockerPolicy

segment.source: You can use the Test-AppLockerPolicy Windows PowerShell cmdlet to determine whether any of the rules in your rule collections will be blocked on your reference device or the device on which you maintain policies.
segment.target: You can use the Test-AppLockerPolicy Windows PowerShell cmdlet to determine whether any of the rules in your rule collections will be blocked on your reference device or the device on which you maintain policies.

segment.source: For the procedure to do this, see Test an AppLocker policy by using Test-AppLockerPolicy.
segment.target: For the procedure to do this, see Test an AppLocker policy by using Test-AppLockerPolicy.

segment.source: Review AppLocker events with Get-AppLockerFileInformation
segment.target: Review AppLocker events with Get-AppLockerFileInformation

segment.source: For both event subscriptions and local events, you can use the Get-AppLockerFileInformation Windows PowerShell cmdlet to determine which files have been blocked or would have been blocked (if the Audit only enforcement setting is applied) and how many times the event has occurred for each file.
segment.target: For both event subscriptions and local events, you can use the Get-AppLockerFileInformation Windows PowerShell cmdlet to determine which files have been blocked or would have been blocked (if the Audit only enforcement setting is applied) and how many times the event has occurred for each file.

segment.source: Membership in the local Administrators group, or equivalent, is the minimum required to complete this procedure.
segment.target: Membership in the local Administrators group, or equivalent, is the minimum required to complete this procedure.

segment.source: Note: If the AppLocker logs are not on your local device, you will need permission to view the logs.
segment.target: Note: If the AppLocker logs are not on your local device, you will need permission to view the logs.

segment.source: If the output is saved to a file, you will need permission to read that file.
segment.target: If the output is saved to a file, you will need permission to read that file.

segment.source: To review AppLocker events with Get-AppLockerFileInformation
segment.target: To review AppLocker events with Get-AppLockerFileInformation

segment.source: At the command prompt, type PowerShell, and then press ENTER.
segment.target: At the command prompt, type PowerShell, and then press ENTER.

segment.source: Run the following command to review how many times a file would have been blocked from running if rules were enforced:
segment.target: Run the following command to review how many times a file would have been blocked from running if rules were enforced:

segment.source: Run the following command to review how many times a file has been allowed to run or prevented from running:
segment.target: Run the following command to review how many times a file has been allowed to run or prevented from running:

segment.source: View the AppLocker Log in Event Viewer
segment.target: View the AppLocker Log in Event Viewer

segment.source: When AppLocker policy enforcement is set to Enforce rules, rules are enforced for the rule collection and all events are audited.
segment.target: When AppLocker policy enforcement is set to Enforce rules, rules are enforced for the rule collection and all events are audited.

segment.source: When AppLocker policy enforcement is set to Audit only, rules are only evaluated but all events generated from that evaluation are written to the AppLocker log.
segment.target: When AppLocker policy enforcement is set to Audit only, rules are only evaluated but all events generated from that evaluation are written to the AppLocker log.

segment.source: Membership in the local Administrators group, or equivalent, is the minimum required to complete this procedure.
segment.target: Membership in the local Administrators group, or equivalent, is the minimum required to complete this procedure.

segment.source: To view events in the AppLocker log by using Event Viewer
segment.target: To view events in the AppLocker log by using Event Viewer

segment.source: Open Event Viewer.
segment.target: Open Event Viewer.

segment.source: To do this, click Start, type eventvwr.msc, and then press ENTER.
segment.target: To do this, click Start, type eventvwr.msc, and then press ENTER.

segment.source: In the console tree under Application and Services LogsMicrosoftWindows, double-click AppLocker.
segment.target: In the console tree under Application and Services LogsMicrosoftWindows, double-click AppLocker.

segment.source: AppLocker events are listed in either the EXE and DLL log, the MSI and Script log, or the Packaged app-Deployment or Packaged app-Execution log.
segment.target: AppLocker events are listed in either the EXE and DLL log, the MSI and Script log, or the Packaged app-Deployment or Packaged app-Execution log.

segment.source: Event information includes the enforcement setting, file name, date and time, and user name.
segment.target: Event information includes the enforcement setting, file name, date and time, and user name.

segment.source: The logs can be exported to other file formats for further analysis.
segment.target: The logs can be exported to other file formats for further analysis.
